topics.title: HTTP Status Codes
topics.description: Test your knowledge of common HTTP Status Codes!

cards.extra: Interim response indicates that everything is okay so far
The server has received and is processing the request, but no response is available yet
the URI of the requested resource has been changed
the URI of requested resource has been changed temporarily
the response has not been modified, so the client can continue to use the same cached version of the response
server could not understand the request due to invalid syntax
the client must authenticate itself to get the requested response
client does not have access rights to the content (client's identity is known to the server)
server can not find requested resource

topics.title: Acronyms
topics.description: Acronyms can often be the most confusing part of learning new technologies. Don't get left behind!

cards.prompt: What does S at the end of HTTPS stand for?

cards.answer: American Standard Code for Information Interchange

cards.extra: a line or two of code at the top of a markup language document, like HTML or XML, which defines the language and standard that the document is adhering to
domain name extension such as .com, .net, or .org
URI and URL are not technically the same thing, but both are used refer to the address of a web page

topics.title: Testing Frameworks
topics.description: Test your knowledge of common testing techniques!

cards.answer: Tests that are run constantly throughout the development process to ensure that everything is working, every time you make a change.
Tests that are run when you add new code to pre-existing code, to ensure that not only do all pieces work individually, but also that they run together correctly without breaking.
The application is run 'end to end' for all user stories that you can think of.

answers: Test specific scenarios in your application
All application components are tested at once
One or more components of the application are tested
Verifies implementation of database and network components
Verifies implementation of individual components and their interconnected behavior

cards.answer: Can mean the code is correct but the environment has changed
Always a regression, some code is broken

cards.prompt: An integration test an use real containers, databases, and networks.

answers: Should take no longer than 5 minutes to run all test
Run only a few times during a products lifecycle, very time consuming
Can take several hours to run all test

cards.prompt: Which of the following is not a type of testing?

answers: Write all code first, then go back a write tests
Write code to fulfill a behavior, then write tests
Write tests to test a behavior, then write code

cards.prompt: The goal of Unit Testing is to find unexpected bugs.
cards.extra: Unit Testing is used to robustly design software components. Only during code refactoring could you expect Unit Testing to find unexpected bugs.

cards.prompt: Changes to another part of your code base could cause Unit tests related to a different feature to fail.
cards.extra: Unit Tests do not contain any knowledge or assumptions about another part of your code base that is not being tested by that test suite.

cards.answer: A block of unit tests that are closely related. They test the same function or similar parts of the code base.
